poem:
**Englishness Unseen**

Chesil shingle whispers past,  
hedgerows cradle silent tales.  
Turkey oaks, Chiltern-raised,  
stand in stillness, foreign yet familiar.  
Beneath the surface of liberal dreams,  
elegy blooms in red and white,  
roots tangled in wildflower fields,  
an Englishness invisible,  
seen with an Irish eye,  
echoes faint  
yet deeply felt.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "What We Can Know by Ian McEwan review – the limits of liberalism The sheer Englishness of Ian McEwan’s fiction may not be fully visible to his English readers. But it is clearly, and amusingly, visible to at least this Irish reader. It isn’t just McEwan’s elegiac, indeed patriotic, attentiveness to English landscapes – to the wildflowers and hedgerows and crags, to the “infinite shingle” of Chesil Beach, to the Chilterns turkey oak in the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
